lines.text: Is there a Mrs. Cruikshank...?
Yes.
But you're divorced.
No...

[Regina's face falls]
Oh.

[Brian/Adam gets out his wallet to show her the picture]
My mother, she lives in Detroit, you'd like her, she'd like you too.
You're blocking my view.
Ohh... which view would you prefer?
The one you're blocking.
Of course, you won't be able to lie on your back for a while but then you can lie from any position, can't you?
All right, get set for the story of my life.
Fiction or non-fiction?
Well, wasn't it Shakespeare that said, "When strangers do meet in far off lands, they should e'er long see each other again"?
Shakespeare never said that!
How do you know?
It's terrible. You just made it up.
Well, it sounds right...
[opening the phone booth to see Regina]
[Regina screams]
What are you doing in here?
I'm having a nervous breakdown.
Do we know each other?
Why, do you think we're going to?
How would I know?
Because I already know an awful lot of people, so until one of them dies I couldn't possibly meet anyone else.
Well, if anyone goes on the critical list, let me know.
What do I have to do to satisfy you? Become the next victim?
That's a start anyway.
[Gideon is looking at Charles' body in the coffin and begins to sneeze violently]
He must've known Charles pretty well.
How can you tell?
He's allergic to him.
It is infuriating that your unhappiness does not turn to fat!
Well, what did you expect me to say? That a pretty girl with an outrageous manner means more to an old pro like me than a quarter of a million dollars?
I don't suppose so.
Well, it's a toss-up, I can tell you that.
What did you say?
Hasn't it occurred to you that I'm having a tough time keeping my hands off you?
[Regina is stunned]
Oh, you should see your face.
What's the matter with it?
It's lovely.
[Regina drops her knife and fork]
What's the matter now?
I'm not hungry anymore; isn't it glorious?
[Touching the cleft in his chin]
How do you shave in there?
So it's goodbye Alexander Dyle and welcome home Peter Joshua.

[shakes his head]
Sorry the name is Adam Canfield.
Adam Canfield? Wonderful! Do you realize you've had three names in the past two days? I don't even know who I'm talking to any more!
We didn't steal it, there's no law against stealing stolen money.
Of course there is!
There is?
Yes!
When did they pass such a silly law?
This is a ludicrous situation. I can think of a dozen men who are just longing to use my shower.
In my room. Asleep.
And you, Mrs. Lampert?
I was, too.
In Mister Dyle's room?
No, in my room.
Obviously you're telling the truth, for why would you invent such a ridiculous story?
Why do you think Tex did it?
Because I really suspect Gideon and it's always the person you don't suspect.
Do women find it feminine to be so illogical, or can't they help it?
I'm in the book.
Are you?
Charles is.
Is there only one Charles Lampert?
Lord I hope so!
Silvie, I am going to get a divorce.
From Charles?
He's the only one husband I have.
[first lines]
Oh, la!
Don't tell me, you didn't know it was loaded. Sylvie! Oh. Can't he do something constructive, like start an avalanche or something?
How about making me vice president in charge of cheering you up?
[Tearing filter off cigarette]
I can't stand these things... it's like drinking coffee through a veil.
Do you know what's wrong with you?
No, what?
Nothing!

We use the guillotine in this country. I have always imagined that the blade, coming down, causes no more than a slight tickling sensation on the back of the neck. It is only a guess, of course. I hope none of you ever finds out for certain.

[pondering]
Is there a Mrs. Dyle?
Yes...
[Reggie's face drops]
but we're divorced!

[Reggie smirks]
I thought that was Peter Joshua?
I am just as difficult to live with as he was.
Now we wait. With our mouths shut.

[yawns]
Sorry about that.
She batted them pretty little eyes at you, and you fell for it like an egg from a tall chicken!
[the third murder has just been discovered]
Three of them. All in their pyjamas? C'est ridicule! What is it, some new American fad?
Heroin, peppermint-flavored heroin.
Come in. I've got something that stings like crazy.
You're the kind of girl who'd have something like that.

[watching Reggie light another one of his cigarettes, immediately after snuffing one out she had barely puffed]
Do you know what these things cost over here?
We'll have lots of sons and name them all after you.
Here it comes, the fatherly talk. You forget I'm already a widow.
Well, so was Juliet, at fifteen.
I'm not fifteen.
Well, that's your trouble. You're too old for me.
Brian Crookshank. Serves me right if I get stuck with that one.
Well, who asked you to get stuck with any of them?

[explaining a puppet show]
The man and woman are married.
I can see that. They're batting each other over the head.

[Reggie is sitting on his lap and kissing him]
Reggie, cut it out.
OK.
[stops kissing him]
Well now what are you doing?
Cutting it out.
Who told you to do that?
You did.
Oh I'm not through protesting yet.

[smirks]
Oh.
[resumes kissing him]
Cut it out.
Alex, I think I love you.
[They kiss]
Well, here we are.
Where?
On the street where you live.
Not until you proof to me that you're really Brian Crookshank.
All right, one day next week I'll put it on a marriage license. How about that...?

[interrupting]
Quit stalling. I want some identification, now!
I wouldn't lie on a license. I could go to jail...

[interrupting]
You can't prove it to me, can you? You're still trying to - Marriage license! Did you say marriage license?
Now don't change the subject, just give me the stamps.
Oh! Oh, I love you Adam, Alex, Peter, Brian, whatever your name is. Oh, I love you. I hope we have a lot of boys and we can name them all after you.
Before we start that, may I have the stamps?
How would you like a spanking?
How would you like a punch in the nose? Stop treating me like a child.
I don't understand. Why do you want a divorce?
Because I don't love him and he doesn't love me.
That's no reason to get a divorce!
Wow, when you come on, you come on, don't you?
Oh, come on!
Hello, Mr. Dyle.
Reggie?
Well, that's the only name I've got.
Is there a Mrs. Canfield?
Yes...

[both]
But we're divorced.
Is there a Mrs. Joshua?
Yes, but we are divorced.
Oh, that wasn't a proposal. I'm just curious.
This nose tells me when you are lying. It is never mistaken, not in 23 years. This nose will make me commissioner of police.
Well, you know I'd tell you if I had it.
Oh *naturally*, just like I'd tell you if I had it.
*Naturally*. And that goes for Herman too.
*Naturally*.
[after Dyle sees Herman Scobie hanging from the edge of the building]
How are you doing?
HOW DO YOU THINK?
If you get bored, try writing 'Love Thy Neighbor' a hundred times on the side of the building!
Is there a Mr. Lampert?
Yes.
Good for you.
No it isn't, I'm getting a divorce.
Please! Not on my account.
Why do people have to tell lies?
Usually it's because they want something. They are afraid the truth won't get it for them.
You know, I can't help feeling sorry for Scobie. Wouldn't it be nice if we were like that?
What, like Scobie?
No, Gene Kelly.
Any minute now we could be assassinated. Would you do anything like that?
What, assassinate someone?
No, swing down from there on a rope to save the woman you love. Like the Hunchback of Notre Dame.

[turns and sees Notre Dame]
What? Who put that there?
I'm sorry I thought you were the murderer.
Are you a real cowboy?
Sure am, kid.
So where's your gun?
[Tex takes out his gun and twirls it]
Will you put that thing away!
[last lines]
Before we start that, can I have the stamps?
I've got something here. I've got liverwurst, liverwurst, chicken, and liverwurst.
No, thank you.
I'm sorry.
No, for a few minutes, they were mine. That is enough.
That's no reason to get a divorce! With a rich husband and this year's clothes, you won't find it difficult to make some new friends.
Look, I admit I came to Paris to escape American Provincial, but that doesn't mean I'm ready for French Traditional.
Stop, Mrs. Lampert, or I'll kill you!
It won't get you the stamps, Dyle. You'll still have to come out, and I'm not likely to miss at this range.

Maybe not, but it takes a lot of bullets to kill me. They left me there with five in my leg and my stomach. They knew I was alive, but they left me there. I spent ten months in a German prison camp with nothing to stop the pain. They left me there. They deserved to die.
But I had nothing to do with it.
I'll kill you too. It won't make any difference... I've come too far to turn back. I swear I'll kill you!
Which one are you?
A truthful white-foot.
Come in. Sit down.
Why, do you want to look at my feet?
Yes.
[sits on his lap]
I bluffed the Old Man out of the last pot. With a pair of deuces.
What's so depressing about that?
Well, I mean, if I can do it, what are the Russians doing to him?
Oh, poor old Herman. It seems like him and good luck always was strangers. Well, maybe now he'll meet up with his other hand some place.
Come on. My mama didn't raise no stupid children.

[Offering advice to Reggie and Mr. Dyle, after three murdered people have been found, all wearing pajamas]
And if I were you, I wouldn't stay in my pajamas. Good night.
Mrs. Lampert, do you know what C.I.A. is?
I don't suppose it's an airline, is it?
Oh, I don't know who anybody is...
Reggie, I beg you. Just trust me once more.
Why should I?

[slight pause]
I can't think of a reason in the world why you should.

[Describing the stamps to Reggie]
Ah, the best for last. Le chef d'oeuvre de la collection. The masterpiece. The most valuable stamp in the world. It's called the Gazette Maldave. It was printed by hand on colored paper... and marked with the initials of the printer. Today it has a value of 100,000 dollars.
I'm not a thief, madame. I knew there was some mistake...
Do you understand French?
Not a word. I'm still having trouble with English.
Are you really Carson Dyle's brother?
Would you like to see my passport?
Passport? What kind of proof is that?
Well, would you like to see where I was tattooed?
Yes.
All right. We'll drive around that way.
[groans]
All right, get set for the story of my life.
Fiction or non-fiction?
Eh, why don't you shut up?
Well!
Are you going to listen?
Go on...

Now, when I was a young man, my father expected me to go into his business. Umbrella frames. That's what he made. A sensible business, I suppose, but I didn't have the sense in those days to be sensible.

[looking skeptical]
I suppose all this is leading somewhere...
Well, it led me away from umbrella frames, for one thing. But that left me without any honest means of support.
What do you mean?
Well, in this highly competitive world, when a man has no profession, there isn't much choice, so I began looking for people who had more money than they needed... including some they'd barely miss.
You mean you're a thief?
Well, that's not exactly the term I'd have chosen, but it sort of captures the spirit of the thing.
I don't believe it!
Alex, how can you tell if anyone's lying or not?
You can't.
There must be some way.

No, no. There's an old riddle about two tribes of Indians. The Whitefeet always tell the truth, and the Blackfeet always lie. So one day you meet an Indian. You say, "Hey, Indian, what are you, a truthful Whitefoot or a lying Blackfoot? He says, "I'm a truthful Whitefoot." But which is he?
Well, why couldn't you just look at his feet?
Because he's wearing moccasins.
Well, then he's a truthful Whitefoot, of course.
Well, why not a lying Blackfoot?
Which one are you?
A truthful Whitefoot.

[as he's rubbing her feet in the cab]
You didn't have to chase me so hard... I'm sorry I thought you were the murderer. But how was I to know he was as big a liar as you are?
Is that all the gratitude I get for saving your hide? Here, rub your own blinking foot!
Could I have one of those?
One of what?
I think Tex did it.
